data.text: What Do You Think About Camping in a Churchyard?
What's the thoughts on camping in churchyards? Mown lawns, quiet neighbours, usually water, and if weather is bad then the church porch can offer shelter.
I would say setting up like you have there is a no no. Possibly around the edges yes. Try to show some respect no wonder we get a bad name
data.author: Martin Hendy

data.text: Hope the grave yard shift don‚Äôt want to dig a grave plot there otherwise you may find yourself buried!

data.text: Might seem ideal on paper but best not to out of respect, imagine the family of the deceased would be upset by someone using the area as a makeshift campsite.
data.author: Robert Brown

data.text: Wouldn‚Äôt do it myself personally as I wouldn‚Äôt want it done next next to one of my deceased relatives.

data.text: Wrong on so many levels.

data.text: It was after a long day making up distance to get back on track after losing a day when I left my small rucksack containing all my money, cards etc. in Plymouth. Did near on 100 miles this day and 80+ the next to bring myself back on track to my target finish date. I found the spot, stashed my stuff and went to the pub. The pub didn't want me camping in their beer garden despite me spending near on ¬£50 on food and drink there. Pitched at nightfall and left at 6.30am. Top tip: take a spare bank card and put in a different bag.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: regardless it‚Äôs disrespectful, you maybe should have spoken to the pub beforehand.

data.text: i would not camp in a cemetery but good for water and often sat in them had a brew and lunch always benches with a backrest to sit on

data.text: Besides everything mentioned, I'd certainly feel uncomfortable camping so near to civilisation, unless you've found some unusually remote graveyard somewhere

data.text: shows lack of respect for me

data.text: Sorry but very bad form. You‚Äôve come to pay your respects and there‚Äôs someone camping near the grave of your loved one? There‚Äôs limitless options in fields, woods and roadsides and you choose a graveyard? Dare I ask about the loo arrangements? Please show some respect and more to the point don‚Äôt ruin it for the rest of us.
data.author: Iain Christie

data.text: If it was the last place on earth maybe ü§î

data.text:
Seems similar in principle to this. There might even be a toilet you can use for a donation to the roof repair fund. Most historic churchyards haven't accepted new burials for quite some time, so wh while I get relatives of newly deceased individuals being uncomfortable, it's also potentially unlikely. https://champing.co.uk
Champing‚Ñ¢ - The simple concept of camping in ancient churches

data.text: Graveyards are for the deceased to rest NOT someone with a tent. Disgusting to pitch a tent so close to a grave. Why not pitch along the edge? I would say I'm shocked but these days people are so disrespectful nothing shocks anymore.

data.text: What‚Äôs so disrespectful? Neither he is tarnishing the memory, neither disrespecting a place.

data.text: I think the advice here Andrew, is it‚Äôs not recommended practice and perhaps a bit disrespectful. I suggest everybody else just calms down a bit and takes it for what it is. Don‚Äôt set up camp in a cemetery.
